thread.title: Murder suspect faces court 25 years on
thread.title_full: Murder suspect faces court 25 years on

title: Murder suspect faces court 25 years on
text:
Share on Twitter 
They were three Aboriginal children who lived on the same street and were killed within the space of five months in the northern NSW town of Bowraville. 
And today — 25 years’ after their deaths — a man has arrived at Newcastle Local Court to face murder charges in relation to two of them. 
The suspected serial killer — who cannot be named for legal reasons — was issued with a court attendance notice last December in relation to the deaths of Evelyn Greenup, 4, and Clinton Speedy-Duroux, 16, who disappeared from Bowraville in the early 1990s. 
No one has ever been charged with the murder of 16-year-old Colleen who went missing in September 1990. 
Colleen’s clothes were found weighted down with rocks in the Nambucca River several months after she disappeared while the remains of Evelyn and Clinton were found off the side of a dirt road on the outskirts of Bowraville. Clinton Speedy-Duroux Source: Supplied Evelyn Greenup   man facing court this morning had previously been charged with their murders but was later acquitted after a judge ruled the trials should be heard separately. 
This meant evidence about potential similarities and the man’s links to each of the deaths could not be heard before the same court. Colleen Walker was 16 when she went missing in September 1990. No one has ever been charged over her murder.   appearance of the man today is a major step in the fight for justice for the family of the children. 
Relatives believe the children’s suspected murders were not properly investigated at the time because of racism and were devastated when told their children had simply gone “walkabout”. 
The white man they always suspected of killing their children also lived in the small Bowraville community. 
Last year NSW Police Commissioner Andrew Scipione apologised to the families of the victims and acknowledged the initial police investigation was inadequate. Outgoing NSW Police Commissioner Andrew Scipione lay wreaths in Bowraville with the families of the three murdered children.   
A major stumbling block to a retrial has been the double jeopardy laws which prevent a person from being tried more than once for the same crime. 
But in 2006 the state’s double jeopardy laws were changed to allow a person to be tried for the same crime but only if there was “fresh and compelling evidence”. 
It remains unknown whether evidence that police believe links the killings to each other and the suspect meets the legal definition of “fresh” and is evidence that has not already been “adduced” in court. Michelle Jarrett, the aunt of Evelyn Greenup, with a picture of her aged three.   
In May last year then NSW Attorney-General Gabriel Upton referred the application for a retrial to the NSW Court of Criminal Appeal following a 20-year investigation by police, led by Detective Chief Inspector Gary Jubelin. 
“After careful consideration, I have decided that there should be no further delay in bringing this matter to court,” Ms Upton said. Unsolved murders of three Aboriginal children in the New South Wales country town of Bowraville. Gumbayngirr Rd Bowraville where the 3 children went missing Source: News Limited 
“The best and most transparent way to deal with this tragic case is to make an application for retrial to the NSW Court of Criminal Appeal.” 
In what has been described as uncharted legal territory — it is up to the highest criminal court in the state to decide whether there is “fresh and compelling evidence” to warrant a retrial. 
It is understood that if the matter proceeds to a retrial the NSW Police will then seek an ex-officio indictment to charge the man with the murder of Colleen. 
The suspected killer has always denied any involvement in the children’s deaths.
